Evaluate projections

Source: vignettes/evaluate.Rmd
evaluate.Rmd
library(propop)

Evaluate projections

propop provides a function to compare projections against a benchmark. The benchmark can be the actual population development (i.e., official records) or a base model (e.g., when testing alternative models).

Get the data

To run the evaluation function, we need the benchmark data and the results from the projection.

Get the population records for the canton of Aargau 2019-2022:

data_benchmark <- get_population(
  number_fso = "px-x-0102010000_101",
  year_first = 2018,
  year_last = 2022,
  spatial_units = "- Aargau"
)

Get the parameters for the projection:

data_parameters <- get_parameters(
  year_first = 2019,
  year_last = 2050,
  spatial_units = "Aargau"
)

Get the population projection for 2019-2022:

data_projected <- propop(
  parameters = data_parameters |>
    dplyr::filter(scen == "reference"),
  year_first = 2019,
  year_last = 2050,
  age_groups = 101,
  fert_first = 16,
  fert_last = 50,
  share_born_female = 100 / 205,
  # population records from 2018 as starting point
  population = data_benchmark |>
    dplyr::filter(year == 2018),
  subregional = FALSE
)
#> Running projection for: Aargau
#> âœ” Year: 2019
#> âœ” Year: 2020
#> âœ” Year: 2021
#> âœ” Year: 2022
#> âœ” Year: 2023
#> âœ” Year: 2024

Evaluate 1-year age classes

Letâ€™s first pit the projected population growth against the recorded population development (= benchmark) using one-year age classes (default option). Make sure to pass matching data frames, especially in terms of the year ranges. To remove the start population (2018) from the projection results, you could also use drop_start_year = TRUE.

As a result of prepare_evaluation(), you get the recorded (n_bench) and projected (n_proj) population for each demographic group and year next to each other:

# Combine and pre-process the data
combined <- prepare_evaluation(
  # only keep years from projected period
  data_benchmark = data_benchmark |> dplyr::filter(year > 2018),
  data_projected = data_projected |> dplyr::filter(year > 2018 & year <= 2022)
)

# Show combined data
combined
#> # A tibble: 1,616 Ã— 7
#>     year spatial_unit nat   sex     age n_bench n_proj
#>    <int> <chr>        <chr> <chr> <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl>
#>  1  2019 Aargau       ch    m         0    2611   2499
#>  2  2019 Aargau       ch    m         1    2578   2538
#>  3  2019 Aargau       ch    m         2    2619   2616
#>  4  2019 Aargau       ch    m         3    2581   2594
#>  5  2019 Aargau       ch    m         4    2671   2658
#>  6  2019 Aargau       ch    m         5    2721   2722
#>  7  2019 Aargau       ch    m         6    2621   2618
#>  8  2019 Aargau       ch    m         7    2597   2582
#>  9  2019 Aargau       ch    m         8    2634   2626
#> 10  2019 Aargau       ch    m         9    2643   2640
#> # â„¹ 1,606 more rows

Based on the difference between the observed and projected number of people, compute_measures() then calculates the error and several performance metrics:

compute_measures(combined) |>
  # select demographic group
  dplyr::filter(sex == "m" & nat == "ch" & age == 27) |>
  # round to two digits
  dplyr::mutate(across(perc_e:abs_perc_e, \(x) sprintf(fmt = "%.2f", x))) |>
  DT::datatable(
    filter = "top",
    caption = htmltools::tags$caption(
      style = "caption-side: top; text-align: left; font-weight: bold",
      "Performance measures for projections with 1-year age classes for the
      canton of Aargau 2019-2022."
    )
  )
#> Warning message:
#> The following columns of the output have `Inf` values:
#> ! "perc_e" and "abs_perc_e".
#> â„¹ `Inf` values are probably caused by divisions by zero (e.g., when `n_bench` = 0). Consider using age groups that include more than 1 year.

Evaluate larger age groups

You may also conduct the evaluation for the commonly used age groups 0-19 year olds, 20-64 year olds, and over 64 year olds using the option age_groups = "age_groups_3".

# Combine and pre-process the data
combined_grouped <- prepare_evaluation(
  # only keep years from projected period
  data_benchmark = data_benchmark |> dplyr::filter(year > 2018),
  data_projected = data_projected |> dplyr::filter(year > 2018 & year <= 2022),
  age_groups = "age_groups_3"
)

# Show combined data
combined_grouped
#> # A tibble: 48 Ã— 7
#>     year spatial_unit age       sex   nat   n_bench n_proj
#>    <int> <chr>        <chr>     <chr> <chr>   <dbl>  <dbl>
#>  1  2019 Aargau       age_00_19 f     ch      49005  48866
#>  2  2019 Aargau       age_00_19 f     int     17744  18042
#>  3  2019 Aargau       age_00_19 m     ch      52084  51778
#>  4  2019 Aargau       age_00_19 m     int     19233  19464
#>  5  2019 Aargau       age_20_64 f     ch     151044 150959
#>  6  2019 Aargau       age_20_64 f     int     55871  56132
#>  7  2019 Aargau       age_20_64 m     ch     148433 148413
#>  8  2019 Aargau       age_20_64 m     int     66487  66746
#>  9  2019 Aargau       age_65_   f     ch      59472  59581
#> 10  2019 Aargau       age_65_   f     int      6295   6314
#> # â„¹ 38 more rows

# Compute the performance measures
compute_measures(combined_grouped) |>
  # select demographic group
  dplyr::filter(sex == "m" & nat == "ch" & age == "age_20_64") |>
  # round to two digits
  dplyr::mutate(across(perc_e:abs_perc_e, \(x) sprintf(fmt = "%.2f", x))) |>
  DT::datatable(
    filter = "top",
    caption = htmltools::tags$caption(
      style = "caption-side: top; text-align: left; font-weight: bold",
      "Performance measures for projections with three age classes for the
      canton of Aargau 2019-2022."
    )
  )

Using group weights

Furthermore, you can use weights. The adjusted metric w_abs_perc_e considers that smaller groups tend to have larger forecast errors. As a result, adjusted absolute percentage errors weigh less heavily in smaller groups than in larger groups.

compute_measures(
  combined_grouped,
  weight_groups = c("age")
) |>
  dplyr::filter(year == 2019 & abs_perc_e > .34 & abs_perc_e < .39) |>
  dplyr::mutate(across(perc_e:w_abs_perc_e, \(x) sprintf(fmt = "%.2f", x))) |>
  DT::datatable(
    filter = "top",
    caption = htmltools::tags$caption(
      style = "caption-side: top; text-align: left; font-weight: bold",
      "Performance measures for projections with three age classes for the
      canton of Aargau 2019-2022 (incl. weighted measure)."
    )
  )

propop versus FSO

Instead of comparing the propop projection with population records, we can also use the evaluation function to check how close the propop projection comes to FSOâ€™s projection from the 2020 model.

The differences are extremely small (>= 1):

fso_propop <- prepare_evaluation(
  data_benchmark = data_parameters |>
    dplyr::filter(scen == "reference" & year > 2018) |>
    dplyr::mutate(n = n_projected),
  data_projected = data_projected |>
    dplyr::filter(year > 2018),
  age_groups = "age_groups_3"
) |>
  compute_measures()

fso_propop |>
  dplyr::mutate(across(perc_e:abs_perc_e, \(x) sprintf(fmt = "%.2f", x))) |>
  DT::datatable(
    filter = "top",
    caption = htmltools::tags$caption(
      style = "caption-side: top; text-align: left; font-weight: bold",
      "Comparison of projetions from FSO versus `propop`."
    )
  )
